The last day of school. I remember my excitement of that day as a child, thinking about the summer adventures that were ahead as noisy lockers were cleaned out and goodbyes were said. Little league baseball, swimming, camp, and almost immediately the thoughts of what the next year would be like. Another grade level to look forward to, renewing old friendships, opportunities to make new friends, and who would be my teacher? Summers flew by back then. I looked forward to the last day of school and I couldn't wait for the first day of school.

How different today. Empty hallways and classrooms, no noisy lockers, hugs and high fives replaced by social distancing. And the excitement of next year…

A field trip is one of the best tools that educators can use to provide their students with a variety of experiences. When students leave the classroom, they begin to see the connections between what is happening at school and in the “real world.” They see that what they learn within the walls of the classroom can help them solve the problems they see in the world around them and can have a direct impact on who they become as people. Whether it's a trip to the local library, park, museum, or zoo, each experience that students participate in contributes to their understanding of the world.

To reinvent yourself, take risks, try the same but with a new twist… it gives us all the opportunity to be better then we were last year!!

A student's first day EVER.

A student's first day in a new grade.

A student's first time in a new school.

A parents first time dropping off a kid at school.

A teacher’s first time having students in their OWN classroom.

A teacher's first time in a new grade.
